title: Advanced Navigation Strategies
content:
--- title: "Advanced Navigation Strategies" summary: "Explore advanced navigation techniques for dealing with large-scale, long-term, and multi-robot navigation challenges." tags: [navigation, ros2, nav2, multi-robot, long-term-navigation] keywords: [navigation, ros, nav2, multi-robot, long-term-navigation, exploration, fleet-management] learningObjectives: - "Understand the challenges of long-term autonomy." - "Learn about different strategies for multi-robot coordination." - "Be introduced to the concept of exploration." prerequisites: ["Path Planning and Motion Control in Complex Environments"] outcome: "Readers will have an appreciation for the challenges and opportunities in advanced navigation research." successCriteria: - "Describe a challenge of long-term robot operation." - "Explain the difference between centralized and decentralized multi-robot coordination." - "Define the goal of an exploration algorithm." toolsUsed: [ROS 2, Nav2] relatedConcepts: [multi-agent-systems, long-term-autonomy, exploration-algorithms, fleet-management] --- import Prerequisites from '@site/src/components/Prerequisites'; import LearningObjective from '@site/src/components/LearningObjective'; import Outcome from '@site/src/components/Outcome'; import SuccessCriteria from '@site/src/components/SuccessCriteria'; import Exercise from '@site/src/components/Exercise'; import Checkpoint from '@site/src/components/Checkpoint'; # Chapter 3: Advanced Navigation Strategies This chapter explores advanced navigation strategies for complex and dynamic environments.

You should have a solid understanding of the Nav2 stack and its core components.
  • Understand the challenges of long-term autonomy.
  • Learn about different strategies for multi-robot coordination.
  • Be introduced to the concept of exploration.
 ## Long-Term Autonomy Most navigation systems are designed to operate for a short period of time. **Long-term autonomy** is concerned with enabling robots to operate for days, weeks, or even months without human intervention. This introduces a new set of challenges, including: - **Life-long mapping:** How can a robot update its map as the environment changes over time? - **Localization recovery:** How can a robot recover its position if it gets lost? - **Battery management:** How can a robot ensure that it always has enough power to complete its tasks and return to a charging station? ## Multi-Robot Coordination For tasks that are too large or complex for a single robot, a team of robots can be used. **Multi-robot coordination** is the problem of getting a team of robots to work together effectively. There are two main approaches: - **Centralized:** A central server makes all the decisions for the team. This is simple to implement but can be a single point of failure. - **Decentralized:** Each robot makes its own decisions based on local information and communication with its neighbors. This is more robust but can be more difficult to design and analyze. ## Exploration **Exploration** is the task of autonomously exploring an unknown environment to build a map. The goal is to choose a sequence of actions that will reveal the most information about the environment in the least amount of time. This is often framed as a "next-best-view" problem, where the robot must decide where to go next to see the most new territory.

What is the main advantage of a decentralized approach to multi-robot coordination?

Read about the different exploration algorithms available in the Nav2 stack. Choose one of the algorithms and run it in a simulated environment. Observe how the robot chooses its path to explore the unknown space.

You are now aware of some of the most challenging and interesting research problems in robot navigation. These are the areas where the next generation of robotics breakthroughs will happen.
  • Describe a challenge of long-term robot operation.
  • Explain the difference between centralized and decentralized multi-robot coordination.
  • Define the goal of an exploration algorithm.
